title: If a defendant corporation is sold what happens to its debt obligations?
question: Just found out that the company I'm suing for fraud (among other things) got sold. Does it mean all their obligations are discharged? Ponzi scheme case with many victims. CEO and CFO are also named defendants in fed. case - we're post discovery and they filed MSJ. CEO had an exec protection insurance policy and filed a claim. What happens now? Thank you
answers: There are not enough facts to give you a good accurate answer. It is important to know if the sale was an asset sale or a stock sale. Typically on a stock sale, the new entity would still be liable for the debt. However, if it was an properly executed asset sale, the new entity would not be liable for prior debts.

...filing an MSJ is a common strategy in order to avoid discovery in debt... most of the time they file that MSJ in order to get out fast and easy..you need strong fight in this level if you did not have enought time for discovery...
Maybe they have insurance but you need to put a fight there.
It is customary the CEOs and CFOsto hide behind the corp as entity to avoid any form of personal liability.
Now many techniques can be used ..On the top of my head what about the UFTA concept...
money trail...who when where...comparison of assets prior and after for CEO CFO...
If they get the MSJ you have a serious problem....there
Everything depends from your lawyers..This is a serious matter that needs lawyers with specialization in fraud and ponzi schemes ..uphill battle..you did not move fast enought to avoid MSJ...
Some lawyers in avvo are also fraud examiners (CFE) and they can help you and counsel you appropriately

There are not enough facts to give you a good accurate answer. However, those kind of details would be unrealistic to expect in this forum, thus you should likewise know the only meaningful advice you're going to get is from a lawyer through a more intimate consultation.

However, if I have your story straight it appears you are sueing a corporation for fraud. Likewise you have named officers of the business. This makes sense because if the officers acted fraudulently that is cause to sue for breach of fiduciary duty of loyalty as well as probably the companion duty of due care. Obviously the duty of loyalty applies to fraud more directly and you can then reach personal assets.

If you have a meritorious case for fraud and you can tie in the sale to some sort of deceitful behavior trying to defraud creditors then you should be able to recover nevertheless by halting the sale as a fraudulent transfer. Filing as soon as possible is key here since you want the claim to attach as soon as possible before the transaction is complete.

Also, it does matter who is buying the corporation. It could be by a corporation in which the officers who committed the original fraud have an interest. Then you open up continuing fraud or alter ego. Anyway, these are all conjectures and there is no way to give you adequate advice without a more meaningful conversation.

I agree with my colleague:

Generally, a corporation's debt obligations stay with the corporation, even if its shares are transferred to a new shareholder.

Beyond that, you are asking quite specific questions. You should retain a business litigator to advise you.

Generally, the debt follows the corporation. It's the corp that owes it, not the stock holders (unless they guaranteed same).
